explanation:
1) MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_: parse_cookies_string calls this function directly when storing cookie name/value. To determine whether the target function (or code executed within its scope) violates the MISRA C for‑loop well‑formedness rule you must inspect the callee’s implementation because any for loops inside that function are considered part of the behaviour executed from within parse_cookies_string. If that callee contains for loops that violate the MISRA rule (e.g. wrong loop counter usage or modification of loop control objects in the body), that could affect a complete compliance analysis of the target function. 

2) MHD_connection_alloc_memory_: this function is called by MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_. Its implementation must be inspected as well because for loops inside it (or any further nested callees) similarly contribute to the behaviour executed as part of the call chain originating in parse_cookies_string. 

3) mhd_assert: this macro/function is invoked in parse_cookies_string (and may expand inline). Because macros can expand into arbitrary code (including for loops or calls to functions that contain for loops), you must examine its definition to be sure no for loops are introduced into the target function via macro expansion.
